column2: We reached Rustchuk on January 10th, but by no means landed on that day.

column2: The landing officer was a Bulgarian, quite a competent man if he could have made the railways give him the trucks he needed. There was a collection of hungry German transport officers always putting in their oars, and being infernally insolent to everybody.

column2: But the big trouble came the next morning when I had got nearly all the stuff aboard the trucks.

column2: A young officer in what I took to be a Turkish uniform rode up with an aide-de-camp.

column2: I noticed the German guards saluting him, so I judged he was rather a swell.

column2: He came up to me and asked me very civilly in German for the way-bills.

column2: I gave him them and he looked carefully through them, marking certain items with a blue pencil.
column3: I gave him them and he looked carefully through them, marking certain items with a blue pencil.

column2: Then he coolly handed them to his aide-de-camp and spoke to him in Turkish.
column3: Then he coolly handed them to his aide de camp and spoke to him in Turkish.

column2: 'Look here, I want these back,' I said.

column2: 'I can't do without them, and we've no time to waste.'
column3: 'I can't do without them, and we've no time to waste.'

column2: 'Presently,' he said, smiling, and went off.
column3: 'Presently,' he said, smiling, and went off.

column2: The street corkscrewed endlessly.
column3: The street corkscrewed endlessly.

column2: Sometimes it seemed to stop; then it found a hole in the opposing masonry and edged its way in.
column3: Sometimes it seemed to stop; then it found a hole in the opposing masonry and edged its way in.

column2: Often it was almost pitch dark; then would come a greyish twilight where it opened out to the width of a decent lane.
column3: Often it was almost pitch dark; then would come a greyish twilight where it opened out to the width of a decent lane.

column2: To find a house in that murk was no easy job, and by the time we had gone a quarter of a mile I began to fear we had missed it.
column3: To find a house in that murk was no easy job, and by the time we had gone a quarter of a mile I began to fear we had missed it.

column2: It was no good asking any of the crowd we met. They didn't look as if they understood any civilized tongue.
column3: It was no good asking any of the crowd we met. They didn't look as if they understood any civilized tongue.

column2: At last we stumbled on it--a tumble-down coffee house, with A. Kuprasso above the door in queer amateur lettering.
column3: At last we stumbled on it-a tumble down coffee house, with a Kuprasso above the door in queer amateur lettering.

column2: There was a lamp burning inside, and two or three men smoking at small wooden tables.
column3: There was a lamp burning inside, and two or three men smoking at small wooden tables.

column2: We ordered coffee, thick black stuff like treacle, which Peter anathematized.
column3: We ordered coffee, thick black stuff like treacle, which peter anathematized.

column2: A negro brought it, and I told him in German I wanted to speak to Mr Kuprasso.
column3: A negro brought it, and I told him in German I wanted to speak to Mr Kuprasso.

column2: He paid no attention, so I shouted louder at him, and the noise brought a man out of the back parts.
column3: He paid no attention, so I shouted louder at him, and the noise brought a man out of the back parts.

column2: He was a fat, oldish fellow with a long nose, very like the Greek traders you see on the Zanzibar coast.
column3: He was a fat, oldish fellow with a long nose, very like the Greek traders you see on the Zanzibar coast.

column2: I beckoned to him and he waddled forward, smiling oilily.
column3: I beckoned to him and he waddled forward, smiling oilily.

column2: Then I asked him what he would take, and he replied, in very halting German, that he would have a sirop.
column3: Then I asked him what he would take, and he replied, in very halting German, that he would have a sirop.

column2: 'You are Mr Kuprasso,' I said.
column3: 'You are Mr Kuprasso,' I said.

column2: 'I wanted to show this place to my friend.
column3: 'I wanted to show this place to my friend.

column2: He has heard of your garden-house and the fun there.'
column3: He has heard of your garden house and the fun there.'

column2: 'The Signor is mistaken.
column3: 'The Signor is mistaken.

column2: I have no garden-house.'
column3: I have no garden house.'

column2: 'Rot,' I said; 'I've been here before, my boy.
column3: 'Rot,' I said; 'I've been here before, my boy.

column2: I recall your shanty at the back and many merry nights there.
column3: I recall your shanty at the back and many merry nights there.

column2: What was it you called it?
column3: What was it you called it?

column2: Oh, I remember--the Garden-House of Suliman the Red.'
column3: Oh, I remember-the Garden House of Suliman the Red.'

column2: He put his finger to his lip and looked incredibly sly.
column3: He put his finger to his lip and looked incredibly sly.

column2: 'The Signor remembers that.
column3: 'The Signor remembers that.

column2: But that was in the old happy days before war came. The place is long since shut.
column3: But that was in the old happy days before war came. The place is long since shut.

column2: The people here are too poor to dance and sing.'
column3: The people here are too poor to dance and sing.'

column2: 'All the same I would like to have another look at it,' I said, and I slipped an English sovereign into his hand.
column3: 'All the same I would like to have another look at it,' I said, and I slipped an English sovereign into his hand.

column2: He glanced at it in surprise and his manner changed.
column3: He glanced at it in surprise and his manner changed.

column2: 'The Signor is a Prince, and I will do his will.' He clapped his hands and the negro appeared, and at his nod took his place behind a little side-counter.
column3: 'The Signor is a Prince, and I will do his will.' He clapped his hands and the negro appeared, and at his nod took his place behind a little side counter.

column2: 'Follow me,' he said, and led us through a long, noisome passage, which was pitch dark and very unevenly paved.
column3: 'Follow me,' he said, and led us through a long, noisome passage, which was pitch dark and very unevenly paved.

column2: Then he unlocked a door and with a swirl the wind caught it and blew it back on us.
column3: Then he unlocked a door and with a swirl the wind caught it and blew it back on us.

column2: We were looking into a mean little yard, with on one side a high curving wall, evidently of great age, with bushes growing in the cracks of it.
column3: We were looking into a mean little yard, with on one side a high curving wall, evidently of great age, with bushes growing in the cracks of it.

column2: Some scraggy myrtles stood in broken pots, and nettles flourished in a corner.
column3: Some scraggy myrtles stood in broken pots, and nettles flourished in a corner.

column2: At one end was a wooden building like a dissenting chapel, but painted a dingy scarlet.
column3: At one end was a wooden building like a dissenting chapel, but painted a dingy scarlet.

column2: Its windows and skylights were black with dirt, and its door, tied up with rope, flapped in the wind.
column3: Its windows and skylights were black with dirt, and its door, tied up with rope, flapped in the wind.

column2: 'Behold the Pavilion,' Kuprasso said proudly.
column3: 'Behold the Pavilion,' Kuprasso said proudly.

column2: 'That is the old place,' I observed with feeling.
column3: 'That is the old place,' I observed with feeling.

column2: 'What times I've seen there!
column3: 'What times I've seen there!

column2: Tell me, Mr Kuprasso, do you ever open it now?'
column3: Tell me, Mr Kuprasso, do you ever open it now?'

column2: He put his thick lips to my ear.
column3: He put his thick lips to my ear.

column2: 'If the Signor will be silent I will tell him.
column3: 'If the Signor will be silent I will tell him.

column2: It is sometimes open--not often.
column3: It is sometimes open-not often.

column2: Men must amuse themselves even in war.
column3: Men must amuse themselves even in war.

column2: Some of the German officers come here for their pleasure, and but last week we had the ballet of Mademoiselle Cici.
column3: Some of the German officers come here for their pleasure, and but last week we had the ballet of Mademoiselle Cici.

column2: The police approve--but not often, for this is no time for too much gaiety.
column3: The police approve-but not often, for this is no time for too much gaiety.

column2: I will tell you a secret. Tomorrow afternoon there will be dancing--wonderful dancing!
column3: I will tell you a secret. Tomorrow afternoon there will be dancing-wonderful dancing!

column2: Only a few of my patrons know.
column3: Only a few of my patrons know.

column2: Who, think you, will be here?'
column3: Who, think you, will be here?'

column2: He bent his head closer and said in a whisper--
column3: He bent his head closer and said in a whisper-

column2: 'The Compagnie des Heures Roses.'
column3: 'The Compagnie des Heures Roses.'

column2: 'Oh, indeed,' I said with a proper tone of respect, though I hadn't a notion what he meant.
column3: 'Oh, indeed,' I said with a proper tone of respect, though I hadn't a notion what he meant.

column2: 'Will the Signor wish to come?'
column3: 'Will the Signor wish to come?'

column2: 'Sure,' I said.
column3: 'Sure,' I said.

column2: 'Both of us.
column3: 'Both of us.

column2: We're all for the rosy hours.'
column3: We're all for the rosy hours.'

column2: 'Then the fourth hour after midday.
column3: 'Then the fourth hour after midday.

column2: Walk straight through the cafe and one will be there to unlock the door.
column3: Walk straight through the cafe and one will be there to unlock the door.

column2: You are new-comers here?
column3: You are new comers here?

column2: Take the advice of Angelo Kuprasso and avoid the streets after nightfall. Stamboul is no safe place nowadays for quiet men.' I asked him to name a hotel, and he rattled off a list from which I chose one that sounded modest and in keeping with our get-up.
column3: Take the advice of Angelo Kuprasso and avoid the streets after nightfall. Stamboul is no safe place nowadays for quiet men.' I asked him to name a hotel, and he rattled off a list from which I chose one that sounded modest and in keeping with our get up.

column2: It was not far off, only a hundred yards to the right at the top of the hill.
column3: It was not far off, only a hundred yards to the right at the top of the hill.

column2: When we left his door the night had begun to drop.
column3: When we left his door the night had begun to drop.

column2: We hadn't gone twenty yards before Peter drew very near to me and kept turning his head like a hunted stag.
column3: We hadn't gone twenty yards before peter drew very near to me and kept turning his head like a hunted stag.

column2: 'We are being followed close, Cornelis,' he said calmly.
column3: 'We are being followed close, Cornelis,' he said calmly.

column2: Another ten yards and we were at a cross-roads, where a little _place_ faced a biggish mosque.
column3: Another ten yards and we were at a cross roads, where a little underscore place underscore faced a biggish mosque.

column2: I could see in the waning light a crowd of people who seemed to be moving towards us.
column3: I could see in the waning light a crowd of people who seemed to be moving towards us.

column2: I heard a high-pitched voice cry out a jabber of excited words, and it seemed to me that I had heard the voice before.
column3: I heard a high pitched voice cry out a jabber of excited words, and it seemed to me that I had heard the voice before.
